item.title: Windows 11 Is Making Xbox-Controller Typing Better
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/windows-11-is-making-xbox-controller-typing-better/1100-6530242/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Typing with an Xbox controller on Windows 11--especially handheld devices--should become easier with a new update rolling out. That's because Microsoft is bringing controller functionality found on Xbox Series X|S for keyboards to Windows 11.

The Verge reports all Windows 11 users should see the new Xbox controller feature in the coming weeks. Not only will there be a gamepad-specific layout for touch keyboards, but there will be controller shortcuts too, such as pressing X for backspace or Y for space. This should sound familiar to Xbox console owners when typing on the system. Microsoft's official language for the update is below:

"We have enabled the gamepad keyboard layout for the touch keyboard in Windows 11. This change introduces the ability to use your Xbox controller to navigate and type. This includes button accelerators (example: X button for backspace, Y button for spacebar) additionally the keyboard keys have been vertically aligned for better controller navigation patterns."

Considering this controller support works with Windows 11 mobile devices, this could add fuel to the fire about a recent report saying an Xbox-branded handheld is planned to release later this year. Microsoft is possibly partnering with Asus on the device, which would run Windows and sport Xbox aesthetics. Additionally, Microsoft is apparently also internally developing an Xbox handheld that's eyeing a 2027 launch.

Microsoft Gaming CEO Phil Spencer has talked about an Xbox handheld for a while now, even noting he wants current PC handhelds "to feel like an Xbox." That also parallels a marketing push to remind people that Xbox is more than just a singular console.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Split Fiction Sent Players Through Laser Hell To Win A Trip To See Hazelight's Next Game
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/split-fiction-sent-players-through-laser-hell-to-win-a-trip-to-see-hazelights-next-game/1100-6530239/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Getting past the hardest parts of Split Fiction can be a challenge for anyone, but the game has an even more difficult hidden stage that pushes players to their limits. And as a reward for the first players who made it through Laser Hell together, Hazelight Studios is flying them to Sweden to see its next game.

Spoilers for accessing the secret level to follow.

Via Video Games Chronicle, Laser Hell opens itself up in the Isolation level after players enter the correct sequence of switch presses while on the elevator. When the elevator doors open after that, players controlling Zoe and Mio are thrust into a platforming level guarded by moving lasers that seems like it was made by the most sadistic Super Mario Maker creators.

A pair of Chinese players, sharkOvO and E1uM4y, were the first to post the video of their successful run through the Laser Hell. As a reward, a video of Hazelight founder Josef Fares congratulates the viewer and admits that many in their office can't beat the level. He also invited the first fans to complete Laser Hell to the studio's headquarters in Sweden to see Hazelight's next game, which is still in development. Fares later congratulated sharkOvO and E1uM4y on social media and confirmed that they had earned their trip before promising to reach out.

Congrats to ‚ÄùsharkOvO‚Äù and ‚ÄùE1uM4y‚Äù for finishing the secret challenge ‚ÄùLaser Hell‚Äù in #splitficton. VERY impressive! I will keep my promise and invite you both to Sweden for an early look of our next gameüòé
We¬¥ll be in touch!

‚Äî Josef Fares (@josef_fares) March 19, 2025

Hazelight briefly teased its next game earlier this week, and praised its partnership with EA. In just the weekend after its release at the beginning of March, Split Fiction became EA's No. 2 all-time game on Steam, ahead of Battlefield and even FIFA. Split Fiction has also been earning rave reviews, with a 10/10 review from GameSpot, and it's EA's first game to reach 90 or above on Metacritic since 2012's Mass Effect 2.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Switch 2 Logo Will Appear On Pro Baseball Team's Jerseys This Year
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/with-switch-2-coming-nintendo-logo-will-appear-on-pro-baseball-teams-jerseys/1100-6530240/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Nintendo and The Seattle Mariners have been partners for a long time, and the collaboration is expanding in big way with this year with the professional baseball team adding Nintendo logos to its jerseys.

As you can see in the video below, the Nintendo logo will appear on the left sleeve of players' jerseys this year. The Mariners open their season on March 27, just before the Switch 2 Nintendo Direct on April 2. This is all happening during the same year Nintendo will release the Switch 2.

The Mariners jerseys will feature the red Nintendo logo on their home jerseys and a Nintendo Switch 2 logo on their away jerseys. This makes the Mariners the first MLB team ever to have different marks for home and away games.

Play ball ‚öæ
We‚Äôre thrilled to share we‚Äôre expanding our long-standing relationship with the @Mariners and will be featured on their jersey sleeve this season!
See it for the first time on Opening Day, March 27th! pic.twitter.com/Lig4Aw4bmf

‚Äî Nintendo of America (@NintendoAmerica) March 20, 2025

Former Nintendo president and chairman Hiroshi Yamauchi bought the Seattle Mariners in 1992, with Nintendo of America chairman Howard Lincoln selling the Mario maker's majority stake in 2016 for hundreds of millions of dollars. The company still owns 10% of the baseball franchise.

"Nintendo and the Mariners have been inextricably linked since 1992," Seattle Mariners President of Business Operations Kevin Martinez said. "Now, each time the Mariners take the field, our jersey sleeves will help serve as a reminder of all that Nintendo of America has done for the Northwest community and the team. There isn‚Äôt a better partnership in Major League Baseball. We are grateful for our incredible relationship with Nintendo."

Mariners centerfielder Julio Rodriguez will become an official Nintendo brand ambassador as part of this partnership.

"It's a genuine thrill to be able to partner with such a talented team, including bright stars like Julio," Nintendo's Doug Bowser said.

Whether or not the Nintendo logo will appear on the Mariners jerseys inside Sony's MLB The Show 25 video game is unknown.

As for Nintendo, 2025 is shaping up to be a huge year for the company. As mentioned, the Switch 2 is coming this year, and it's expected to launch around June for about $400.

If you're looking to play a baseball game, Sony's MLB The Show 25 is out now, while Backyard Baseball is coming to mobile soon. You can also grab a Shohei Ohtani skin in Fortnite right now.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Assassin's Creed Shadows - Guides Hub
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/assassins-creed-shadows-guides-hub/1100-6530214/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Assassin's Creed Shadows takes players all the way to Japan during the Sengoku Jidai, the warring states period. As warlords vie for control, it's up to you to aid Yasuke and Naoe, to see how their destinies are intertwined. One is a samurai, a peerless warrior who can go toe to toe against multiple foes. The other, meanwhile, is a shinobi, striking from the darkness to silently eliminate her targets. Our Assassin's Creed Shadows guides hub has everything you need to help you tackle missions and learn about new intricacies in the latest entry to Ubisoft's open-world series.

Table of Contents [hide]

  • Assassin's Creed Shadows guides hub
    • Starter guides
    • Hideout: Resources and utility functions
    • Progression: Missions and objective locations

Assassin's Creed Shadows guides hub

Starter guides

The Assassin's Creed Shadows guides below are primarily for those who are just starting their journey. We discuss basic mechanics, such as gaining Knowledge Points to unlock higher-tier skills, as well as the differences between Yasuke's and Naoe's playstyles.

Playing as Yasuke or Naoe - How to switch between characters

How to get more Knowledge Points

How to increase your health

Hideout: Resources and utility functions

The hideout acts as your main base throughout your playthrough. It's where you can construct additional buildings that offer nifty functions and utility roles. Of course, you also need to amass enough resources.

How to get more mon

How to get hideout resources

How to get more scouts - Scout functions

How to upgrade your gear - Blacksmith functions

Progression: Missions and objective locations

Progressing through a chunk of the campaign in Shadows is quite different compared to its predecessors. That's because many quest objectives aren't readily shown on the map. Instead, you're given general directions and hints as to the whereabouts of your quarry. In the same vein, you'll spend a lot of time hunting down your targets: the members of the Shinbakufu group.

The Golden Teppo: Imai Sokyu, the Tea Merchant, and the Kosode

The Golden Teppo: Should you confront Otama or Wakasa

The Fool: Ise Sadatame and the Messenger

The Fool: The Twisted Tree quest and the Takahashi Clan

We'll continue adding more articles to our Assassin's Creed Shadows guides hub, so stay tuned.

Jason Rodriguez on Google+

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Six Years Outside Wasn't Enough To Kill This Pokemon Sun 3DS Cart
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/six-years-outside-wasnt-enough-to-kill-this-pokemon-sun-3ds-cart/1100-6530237/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

They say diamonds are forever, but Nintendo 3DS game carts might be ready to give that precious material a run for its money. One Pokemon Sun player discovered just how durable the 3DS cart for the game was, as after it appeared to be lost for several years, they located it in their yard and found that it still worked fine.

"I was cleaning outside and I found this, it's my copy of Pokemon Sun from middle school,‚Äù user Lzzz4 shared on the Pokemon Sun and Moon subreddit (via Automaton and Kotaku). "Last time [it] saved [was] November 7, 2018, that's probably around the time I lost it, that means its been outside for about six years and it still works."

While the cartridge did show some obvious signs of wear and tear from being outside for seven years--and the game label was missing--the original save data was still present. Lzzz4's team of Pokemon were ready to resume their journey in the Alolan region, and with over 100 hours logged in the game, they had amassed quite the collection of pocket monsters.

After a long break, the next big entry in the Pokemon franchise will be out later this year. Pokemon Legends Z-A has a release window of late 2025, and last month's Pokemon Presents livestream revealed more details for upcoming events in several of the free-to-play mobile Pokemon games. Outside of the video games, Lego has also teased its first Pokemon set, with the first image for this collaboration featuring a glimpse at series mascot Pikachu.

Darryn Bonthuys on Google+

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
